awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Polynyas in Coastal Antarctica (PICA): Linking Physical Dynamics to Biological Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
During winter, sea-ice coverage along the Antarctic coast is punctuated by numerous polynyas--isolated openings of tens to hundreds of kilometer wide. These coastal polynyas are hotspots of sea ice production and the primary source regions of the bottom water in the global ocean. They also host high levels of biological activities and are the feeding grounds of Emperor penguins and marine mammals. The polynyas are a key component of the Antarctic coastal system and crucial for the survival of penguins and many other species. These features also differ dramatically from each other in timing of formation, duration, phytoplankton growth season, and overall biological productivity. Yet, the underlying reasons for differences among them are largely unknown.  This project studies the fundamental biophysical processes at a variety of polynyas, examines the connection between the physical environment and the phytoplankton and penguin ecology, and investigates the mechanisms behind polynya variability. The results of this interdisciplinary study will provide a context for interpretation of field measurements in Antarctic coastal polynyas, set a baseline for future polynya studies, and examine how polynya ecosystems may respond to local and large-scale environmental changes. The project will include educational and outreach activities that convey scientific messages to a broad audience. It aims to increase public awareness of the interconnection between large-scale environmental change and Antarctic coastal systems.

The main objectives of this study are to form a comprehensive understanding of the temporal and spatial variability of Antarctic coastal polynyas and the physical controls of polynya ecosystems. The project takes an interdisciplinary approach and seeks to establish a modeling system centered on the Regional Ocean Modeling System.  This system links the ice and ocean conditions to the plankton ecology and penguin population. Applications of the modeling system in representative polynyas, in conjunction with analysis of existing observations, will determine the biophysical influences of individual forcing factors. In particular, this study will test a set of hypothesized effects of winds, offshore water intrusion, ice-shelf melting, sea-ice formation, glacier tongues, and ocean stratification on the timing of polynya phytoplankton bloom and the overall polynya biological productivity. The project will also examine how changing polynya state affects penguin breeding success, adult survival, and population growth. The team will conduct idealized sensitivity analysis to explore implications of forcing variability, including local and large-scale environmental change, on Antarctic coastal ecosystems.

por.por_cntn:
This project is to study how physical processes in coastal polynyas around Antarctica affect phytoplankton growth and emperor penguin. To achieve the goal, we i) simulated the ocean circulation and its interaction with the sea ice and ice shelf, ii) analyzed the influence of physical factors, such as winds, air temperature, shelf depth, ice tongue and coastline on the formation of sea ice and dense water in the polynyas, iii) investigated the time it takes to break down the water column stratification in the polynyas in winter, iv) analyzed the dispersal pathways of the dense water formed in the polynyas across the Antarctic continental shelf, v) quantified the amount and sources of the freshwater required to establish the polynya stratification in the springtime, vi) analyze the impact of stratification evolution on the timing and intensity of the phytoplankton bloom in the coastal polynyas, and vii) analyzed the impact of ephemeral polynyas and land-fast ice on the emperor penguin ecology.

Our model simulations indicate that circulation in Antarctic coastal polynyas is intrinsically complex and three-dimensional. Break-down of the water-column stratification in the Antarctica coastal polynyas are controlled by not only the heat loss of the ocean to the atmosphere, but also the lateral circulation in the polynya region. before the dense water formed in the polynya sinks into the bottom, a substantial amount is carried away from the polynya region by the horizontal circulation, which slows down the breakdown of the polynya stratification. Meanwhile, coastal easterly winds suppress the lateral dense water dispersal through onshore Ekman transport; ice tongues suppress the lateral dense water dispersal through modifying the polynya circulation pattern. Both of these processes accelerate breakdown of the polynya stratification. These results provide a framework to quantify the influence of physical factors on polynya stratification and to compare different coastal polynya around the Antarctica in their potential in forming the dense shelf water that supplies the Antarctic Bottom Water.

Our model simulations also demonstrate that sea ice melt is a major freshwater source for establishing the near-surface stratification in the polynyas, which is key for phytoplankton bloom in the spring. Ice shelf melt could provide a substantial amount of fresh water into the polynya region. But the ice shelf melt water tends to be mixed with the surround water and does not contribute much to the near-surface stratification.

Using newly developed fine-scale sea-ice data and historical emperor penguin tracking data, we showed that i) juvenile emperor penguins in summer and early winter spent about half of their travel time within the sea-ice covered region, and they do not use large persistent coastal polynyas; ii) during the daylight, juvenile penguins dove to different depths, and the relative proportion of the deeper dives increases with seasonal progression; iii) the movement of the juveniles is correlated with the ocean mixed layer depths, suggesting that they might feed on prey aggregating at the thermocline depth, and iv) less-recognized small openings in the ice – including cracks, flaw leads and ephemeral polynyas – are major foraging habitats for emperor penguins. We confirmed the key role of ephemeral polynya on the breeding success of emperor penguins from Pointe Géologie over 1978-2018. Specifically, the breeding and fledging success is higher for shorter distance to the open water between August and November. Short distance to the nearest open water access positively influences reproductive success by reducing the commuting time and energy expenditure between colony and food source. Our study transforms the analysis of species responses to sea ice dynamic by using an innovative multidisciplinary approach that integrates sea ice thermodynamics and penguin demography data. Climate window analysis suggests that penguin chick mortality was sensitive to land-fast ice variability between August and November. Snowfall in May also affected hatching success.

This project provided the opportunity to train one postdoctoral researcher, three graduate students, and three undergraduate students. Results of this project have been published in a number of journal articles and disseminated in various professional conferences and seminars. PIs had presented talks on biophysical interactions in Antarctic coastal polynyas in K-12 classrooms, undergraduate schools, and to general public. PIs worked together with an artist and the WHOI media group to produce a 10-minute animation about Antarctica polynya biophysical interaction and the research of this project. The animation was also separated into several short clips for easier distribution. All animations were released to the public domain on Youtube, Facebook and Twitter by the WHOI media office.

We gathered and organized a variety of historical hydrographic and penguin track data in the coastal polynya regions around Antarctica. Those data were scattered in a variety of online and personal databases. Collecting and organizing them and then sharing them on USAP-DC will help make them easier to access and thus aid future studies of the integrated Antarctic system.
